description:
Argentina anserina, commonly known as silverweed or goose-grass, is a perennial herbaceous plant belonging to the Rosaceae family. It is native to various regions of the Northern Hemisphere, including Europe, Asia, and North America.

This species is characterized by its distinctive appearance, with pinnately compound leaves that have silvery-white, silky hairs on the underside, giving the plant a shimmering, silvery-gray appearance. The leaves are arranged in a rosette at the base of the plant, and they produce yellow, five-petaled flowers that bloom during the summer months.

Argentina anserina is a low-growing, spreading plant that typically forms dense mats or carpets on the ground. It is often found in moist, disturbed habitats such as roadsides, pastures, and riverbanks. The plant's rhizomes and stolons allow it to spread and form large colonies, and it is considered a hardy, resilient species that can tolerate a wide range of environmental conditions.

Ecologically, Argentina anserina plays a role in stabilizing soil and providing habitat for various insects and small animals. It has also been used historically in traditional medicine and as a food source, with the leaves and rhizomes being edible and sometimes used in culinary applications.
